timeline.bodyText:
Here we are reading the group (String) from the item and then setting the group (String) back again to the item. We are changing what was written before in the item to then be the group identifier.
Why wasn't it the identifier from the beginning?
Actually, this only makes sense if we are updating the group of an item. Then, I would prefer to have an updateGroup method on the Item and an updateGroupsOnItems on the Landscape. Then, we also wouldn't be exposing implementation details of the landscape and the items to this Resolver.
(about exposing the implementation details, this applies to the other contents of the processmethod too)
timeline.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: The method landscape.getGroup() has some magic to be non-nullable, so here we ensure the item.group field is set to something that really points to a group. Could make an example how Landscape.updateGroupsOnItems might be used?
replies.author: bonndan

replies.bodyText:
Yes, I saw that it uses that Group.COMMON and thanks for your explanation! I am still concerned about the mutability of Item and of the way we expose the internals of the objects.
So if your example means that you would agree to a refactoring (because you call it Landscape.updateGroupsOnItems): yes, please and I'll do the refactoring if you like.
I am still wondering why the identifier can not be set on the item right from the beginning? Why exactly isn't it possible to have such (important) fields immutable right from the beginning when we create an instance of the object?
replies.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText:
You are right about the immutability, although some things cannot be set right from the start. And if we're strict about immutability and side effect free programming, we end in reference update hell (this is still a graph with lots of references).
My idea was that all graph components are value objects without much business logic. The logic was meant to reside in the resolvers as far as possible. So we have small units (resolvers) for one dedicated purpose and small value objects.
Obviously the landscape.getGroup() method does too much, and I'd rather go the other way and refactor even more logic out of the graph components.
replies.author: bonndan

replies.bodyText: Ok, I get that about the resolvers and the value object - that approach is fine. Since I lack the overview of how the value objects are used, I was concerned about the objects having an invalid state (in a field such as an identifier). If only a designated resolver manages them, and the logic resides inside of that - that should be fine.
replies.author: mfbieber

timeline.bodyText: The comment: how does this happen? I could not see it from the implementation of getGroup() or elsewhere?
timeline.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: The input DTOs might not have the group reference, and all following resolvers might fail to find or set a group. So this is a fallback. I'll add this explanation to the code.
replies.author: bonndan

replies.bodyText: Ok, so it is happening inside of the Group, now I see it.
replies.author: mfbieber

timeline.bodyText: This returns the JGraphXConfig, which is not related to JGraphX anymore - or am I wrong? Shouldn't we rename the method and the config class?
timeline.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: yes, and this also requires updating the documentation.
replies.author: bonndan

replies.bodyText: done. also separated configs into two: one for group layout, one for layout within groups
replies.author: bonndan

timeline.bodyText: What could we use instead if this is deprecated?
timeline.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: This was an early approach to use dld4e (see https://github.com/bonndan/dld4e-headless) to draw landscapes, but it lacked automatic layouting. It was kept in case it could become a plugin (#14) or somebody might be interested to use it with the automatic layouting. For now I'd say there is no replacement.
replies.author: bonndan

replies.bodyText:
So, it is deprecated but we have no replacement?
I still don't understand what to do about the Dld4eRenderer :) If it is deprecated it means that we don't want it to be used anymore. We should add a comment on what to use instead.
Otherwise, if we want to keep it, it should not be deprecated.
replies.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: Actually I am too lazy to reimplement dld4e rendering with with new layout, although it might not take too long. I know it's in the repo, but I'm still afraid it will be forgotten if we'd delete it. If we're strict then it should be deleted.
replies.author: bonndan

replies.bodyText: Mhm, well you decide. My opinion is: get rid of it. If it is important, we have the VCS to get the code back ;)
replies.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: Otherwise, it wasn't important 😸
replies.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: Removed it. 😿
replies.author: bonndan

timeline.bodyText: The contents of this collection are updated, but never queried.
timeline.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: I would not repair that old code.
replies.author: bonndan

timeline.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: ... because we now need the inverse direction, too. JGraphX handled that before it was removed. I'll remove it.
replies.author: bonndan

timeline.bodyText: Why are we using LandscapeImpl instead of the interface?
timeline.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: As written in our chat, the LandscapeImpl is the real graph, and the Landscape interface might not make too much sense anymore.
replies.author: bonndan

replies.bodyText: Ok, if it does not make sense anymore, how about deleting it?
replies.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: Yes, but that takes some days of refactoring. It's not adding business value and not scope of this feature. I've added #212
replies.author: bonndan

timeline.bodyText: Do we need a LinkedHashMap, or could it be a HashMap? (I don't think that we have memory problems with nivio, just to understand)
timeline.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: It is used to ensure that insertion sequence is maintained. Otherwise layout might receive the items in random order, leading to random results.
replies.author: bonndan

timeline.bodyText: Why don't we use the interface Layouter?
timeline.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: I've pushed a change. Please see if you agree with it. This code is likely to change later when there are more than just one layouter and render implementations.
replies.author: bonndan

replies.bodyText: Yes, if instantiation in the constructor makes sense because we don't need a fresh layouter each time we call getSVG(), sure, why not. This was just intended as a question to understand how we are using interfaces, and so on :)
replies.author: mfbieber

timeline.bodyText: @BilligsterUser: nice that you fixed that error! Could you also write a test that fails with the old implementation and now passes?
timeline.author: mfbieber

timeline.message: [#204] improved and explained group resolving fallback

added some tests for GroupQueryResolver that point out some potential problems - needs fix

timeline.bodyText:
This list contains the same Item twice. This is because the items are just added to the modifiable Collection in Group.
I would refactor this to add a method addItem to Group that does not add items twice (or use a Set) and to have an unmodifiable Collection instead.
timeline.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: As you suggested we are now using a Set.
replies.author: bonndan

replies.bodyText: The unmodifiable Collection thing is a bit too much at the moment. We are constantly updating the collections in the indexing phase, and having side-effect free copies of copies of copies does not seem worth the effort to me.
replies.author: bonndan

replies.bodyText: Ok, I guess most of my suggestions would require some other patterns in our code, which can be hard to implement now into the existing code base with it's patterns already in place.
replies.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: Yes. Please feel free to open tickets for enhancement proposals or simply extend #212
replies.author: bonndan

timeline.bodyText:
This shows what has to be done to have valid objects (instantiation and setting of things), only to not have a NPE.
I am not even sure if this is how the objects are intended to be used 😞, which means that somehow it is not straightforward and thus potentially unsafe.
I also did not really understand why we have Group and GroupDescription both implementing GroupItem. These seem to do almost the same things. There are several casts to these objects, which are really hard to get rid of.
timeline.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText:
Please see LandscapeFactory, it now sets up a proper landscape. We might think about more safety measures though.
Concerning Group and GroupDescription: #212 .
replies.author: bonndan

timeline.bodyText: The query condition has to be the lowercased identifier. Is this intentional? See the other test below.
timeline.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: Good point. We must make sure that querying is not case-sensitive.
replies.author: bonndan

timeline.bodyText: This aims for the las stream of the process() method. The groups are not updated on the landscape, only getGroup(somethingInvalid) returns Group.COMMON. Is this intentional?

replies.bodyText: Has been refactored.
replies.author: bonndan

timeline.bodyText:
groups can be an empty Map, so null was returned before. Is my change how it was intended to be?
If yes, do we need that COMMON logic inside of Group?
timeline.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: Has been refactored.
replies.author: bonndan

replies.bodyText: Alright, but the resulting landscape still does not have a group, is this intentional?
replies.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText:
In addition, if you enable the process_containsCommonGroupIfGroupWasEmpty() in GroupQueryResolverTest, you should see:
java.util.NoSuchElementException: No value present

...
replies.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText:
I added a (passing) Test that does exactly the same as the other mentioned here, but that uses a Landscape from the LandscapeFactory.
For a safety mechanism to use the Landscape correctly: isn't it possible to enforce the same things that the LandscapeFactory does via the Landscape's constructor?
replies.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: Yes :)
replies.author: bonndan

replies.bodyText: An that get() on the optional in GroupQueryResolver should have a preceding ifPresent() check and an orElse() handling :)
replies.author: mfbieber

replies.bodyText: I am working on it.

mfbieber
